statement.p:
Use your calculator to graph y^2 − x^2 = 1 in the window [-6,6]\times [-4,4]. First, solve the equation for y. (You should get two functions.) y_1= \underline{\qquad\qquad\qquad}\qquad \text{ and }\qquad y_2= \underline{\qquad\qquad\qquad}
The graph of this equation is a .
The graph has vertices at and .
Now add to your graph the lines y = x and y = -x. These are the asymptotes of the hyperbola.

Use the calculator to graph x^2 − y^2 = 1 in the window [-6,6]\times [-4,4]. (Follow the steps above for Problem 1.)
What are the vertices of this hyperbola?
What are the asymptotes?
How does this hyperbola differ from the one in Problem 1?

introduction.p:
For Problems 9 and 10:
Find the equation for the hyperbola.
Use your equation to complete the table.

li.p: Graph x^2 - y^2 = 4, x^2 - y^2 = 1, and x^2 - y^2 = 0 on the same set of axes. What do you observe?
Graph 4x^2 - y^2 = 16, 4x^2 - y^2 =4, and 4x^2 - y^2 =0 on the same set of axes. What do you observe?
Graph x^2 - y^2 = 0. (Hint: Factor the left side of the equation and use the zero-factor principle to write two equations, then graph them.) Describe your graph.

introduction.p:
For problems 1318:
Graph the hyperbola.
Give the exact coordinates of any four points on the hyperbola.
For Problems 1922, write an equation for the hyperbola with the properties given.

statement.p: Center at (6,-2), a = 1, b = 4, opening left and right
Center at (-1, 5), a = 6, b = 8, opening up and down
One vertex at (1, -2), one end of the vertical conjugate axis at (-5, 1)
One vertex at (-1, 3), one end of the horizontal conjugate axis at (-5, 1)

introduction.p: For Problems 2328, name the graph of the equation and describe its main features.

answer.p: Hyperbola; center \left(\dfrac{-1}{8},-1 \right) , transverse axis vertical, a^2=\dfrac{15}{65} , b^2=\dfrac{15}{16}

introduction.p: Problems 2932 deal with the cooling tower at an electricity generating facility. The shape of the tower, called a hyperboloid, is obtained by rotating a portion of the hyperbola ~\dfrac{x^2}{100^2}-\dfrac{y^2}{150^2}=1 around the y-axis.

statement.p: The base of the cooling tower is 360 feet below the center of the hyperbola. What is the diameter of the base?
The top of the cooling tower is 200 feet above the center of the hyperbola. What is the diameter of the top?
The diameter of the tower first decreases with height and then increases again. There are two heights at which the tower's diameter is 250 feet. Find the greater of the two heights.
Find the height at which the tower's diameter is 200 feet.
